response.answer_text: Before entering this discussion, it is necessary to emphasize Aristotle's view of a 'good life' was limited exclusively to men (but not just any men, they had to be of correct social status.) Aristotle acknowledges that luck has a role to play in the good life, but to what extent does luck effect the good life? If the good life is dependent on external factors, then it would appear that it could not be considered self-sufficient. However, Aristotle argues that the good life is self-sufficient, and communally self-sufficient. Luck's effect on the good life was much greater than what Aristotle was prepared to acknowledge. The task of reason was to teach humans how to act virtuously, and the exercise faculties in accordance with virtue. The good life, then, was defined by Aristotle as the activity of the soul in accordance with virtue. Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy. Virtue consisted of intellectual virtue and moral virtue. Intellectual virtue was comprised of theoretical wisdom, practical wisdom and understanding. Experience and time were necessary requirements for the development of intellectual virtue. Aristotle identified many that could not lead the good life. Women, slaves and the lower classes (trades people and farmers) were unable to lead the good life since they could not make their own decisions, nor could they choose an action for its own sake. Children were excluded as they had not yet had occasion to practice the virtues, particularly intellectual virtues. Those who had experienced great loss were unable to lead the good life since it would be difficult to learn new friendships and friendship was a necessary requirement for leading the good life. Even the gods, according to Aristotle, could not lead the good life since they found their own lack of limit restricting. If everything was left up to luck for all the needed and necessary conditions for leading the good life, good life would be outside one's control. Aristotle argued that limiting the scope of the external factors that affected the good life would make the good life too limited and filled with frailty. Aristotle's thoughts about life and its meaning are basically to be found in his work Nicomachean Ethics (Ἠθικὰ Νικομάχεια; Ēthika Nikomakheia), which is about ethics (as the title suggests), human virtues, the golden mean etc. His initial argumentation about the meaning of life is the following one: Every purposeful action in this world pursues a certain desirable aim.There are a lot of aims, but the highest one is eudaimonia (εὐδαιμονία). The term means "happiness" or "welfare", but also transcents this meaning; it is a philosophical term that had been used by other philosophers before Aristotle; it refers to a certain way of life.Since eudaimonia is the highest aim and also a practical one (it has to do with one's actions and life), it is essential that politics care about it; besides, the part (every single human being alone) is less necessary than the whole (society). Eudaimonia is connected to politics.The problem is that people do not agree on the exact meaning of eudaimonia. There are even some who believe that living a hedonistic life is a kind of happiness.Since people tend to pursue virtues for their own sake and not only for their practical usefuleness or for the happiness they cause, we can infer that virtue human life and eudaimonia are profoundly connected with being virtuous.To understand what man's true eudaimonia really is, one has also to inspect what man's uniqueness and specialized work (ergon; ἔργον) are about.Man's uniqueness emanates from his logos (λόγος; speach and/or reason). Reason has a role to play in man's good life too.Good life is not only about contemplation, but also about acting/doing.INFERENCE: The Good of man is the active exercise of his soul's faculties in conformity with excellence or virtue, or if there be several human excellences or virtues, in conformity with the best and most perfect among them.
